etymologies: Old English strācian ‘caress lightly’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch streek ‘a stroke’, German streichen ‘to stroke’, also to strike. The earliest noun sense ‘blow’ is first recorded in Middle English

definitions: an act of hitting or striking someone or something; a blow

examples.text: he received three strokes of the cane

shortDefinitions: act of hitting or striking person or thing

definitions: a method of striking the ball in sports or games.
shortDefinitions: method of striking ball in sports or games

definitions: an act of hitting the ball with a club, as a unit of scoring
shortDefinitions: act of hitting ball with club, as unit of scoring

definitions: the sound made by a striking clock

examples.text: the first stroke would belt out from the clock

shortDefinitions: sound made by striking clock

definitions: a mark made by drawing a pen, pencil, or paintbrush in one direction across paper or canvas

examples.text: the paint had been applied in careful, regular strokes

shortDefinitions: mark made by drawing pen, pencil, or paintbrush in one direction

definitions: a line forming part of a written or printed character.
shortDefinitions: line forming part of written or printed character

definitions: a short printed or written diagonal line typically separating characters or figures.
shortDefinitions: short printed or written diagonal line separating characters or figures

definitions: an act of moving one's hand across a surface with gentle pressure

examples.text: massage the cream into your skin using light upward strokes

shortDefinitions: act of moving one's hand across surface with gentle pressure

definitions: a movement, especially one of a series, in which something moves out of its position and back into it; a beat

examples.text: the ray swam with effortless strokes of its huge wings

shortDefinitions: each of series of movements in which something moves out of its position

definitions: the whole motion of a piston in either direction.
shortDefinitions: whole motion of piston in either direction

definitions: the rhythm to which a series of repeated movements is performed

examples.text: the rowers sing to keep their stroke

shortDefinitions: rhythm to which series of repeated movements is performed

definitions: a movement of the arms and legs forming one of a series in swimming

examples.text: I slipped into the water and swam a few strokes

shortDefinitions: movement of arms and legs forming one of series in swimming

definitions: style of moving the arms and legs in swimming

examples.text: front crawl is a popular stroke

shortDefinitions: particular style of moving arms and legs in swimming

definitions: (in rowing) the mode or action of moving the oar.
shortDefinitions: (in rowing) mode or action of moving oar

definitions: the oar or oarsman nearest the stern of a boat, setting the timing for the other rowers.
shortDefinitions: oar or oarsman nearest stern of boat, setting timing for other rowers

definitions: a sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis

examples.text: he was left disabled by a stroke
smoking increases the risk of stroke

shortDefinitions: sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by interruption in flow of blood to brain

phrases.text: not do a stroke of work

definitions: move one's hand with gentle pressure over (a surface, especially hair, fur, or skin), typically repeatedly; caress

examples.text: he put his hand on her hair and stroked it

shortDefinitions: move one's hand with gentle pressure over surface

definitions: apply (something) to a surface using a gentle movement

examples.text: she strokes blue eyeshadow on her eyelids

shortDefinitions: apply something to surface using gentle movement

definitions: reassure or flatter (someone), especially in order to gain their cooperation

examples.text: production executives were expert at stroking stars and brokering talent

shortDefinitions: reassure someone

definitions: act as the stroke of (a boat or crew)

examples.text: he stroked Penn's rowing eight to victory

shortDefinitions: act as stroke of

definitions: hit or kick (a ball) smoothly and deliberately

examples.text: Miller calmly stroked three-pointers throughout the tournament

shortDefinitions: hit or kick ball smoothly

definitions: score (a run or point) by hitting or kicking a ball smoothly

examples.text: the senior stroked a two-run single

shortDefinitions: score run or point in such manner

phrases.text: not do a stroke of work
